titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Richard Cardarelli Papers
1969-2005 GLBTQ 2012.09 GLBTQ.2012.09

note.p: First guide to this collection was prepared by Francis Gagliardi, 2006; updated by Lisa Darms, 2010. Revised and input in the AT by Rolande Dupree, 2012.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-04-08T12:19-0400

did.abstract: Richard Cardarelli was a celebate gay activist priest living and working in the Hartford Area for most of his career. He co-founded Dignity/Hartford and celebrated mass with the organization. His papers include subject files which he kept for research and reference, as well as several documents pertaining to Dignity/Hartford and other Dignity organizations around the country. Scrapbooks of photos from various events in which he was involved form a good portion of the collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: There are no restrictions on access to this collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Richard Cardarelli (August 25, 1951 – June 22, 2012) was a gay activist, an ordained Catholic priest and Franciscan Friar. His activism as a gay celebate priest eventually brought him to be excommunicated by the Catholic Church. A native of Connecticut, Cardarelli received his BA in French Literature from St. Michaels College in Vermont. After receiving a teaching certificate from Central Connecticut State College, he began teaching French and Religion at Xavier High School in Middletown, Connecticut. He entered the Capuchin Franciscan Order in 1976. He professed solemn vows in 1981 and was ordained a priest in 1982. He received his Masters of Divinity and a Masters of Theology at the Maryknoll School of Theology and served as chaplain to Mercy High School in Middletown, CT, and later as Director of his province's Office of Peace and Justice. His career as a gay activist began in 1971, the summer of his first gay parade in New York City. He later joined DIGNITY, USA, helping to found the Springfield/Hartford Chapter in 1975. This career paralleled his peace activities which started with his first peace march in Boston in 1969. Once he was assigned to full-time peace and justice activities, he engaged in civil disobedience to protest war, the nuclear arms race, apartheid in South Africa, and homophobia/heterosexism. His arrest at the Supreme Court for gay/lesbian rights made news headlines and his public gay ministry began to be questioned by the church hierarchy. With the support of his superior, he was very public with gay activism and ministry, first and foremost with DIGNITY and then with the Connecticut Coalition for Lesbian and Gay Civil Rights. He engaged in dialogue with local bishops and testified at the State Capitol for gay legislation. He spoke at colleges, on panels for clergy and religious, on television and radio, and continued to march each June in New York City. After DIGNITY was forced out of Catholic facilities around the country, he came out as a gay celibate priest in the press. His priestly faculties were revoked. After he stood with ILGO in New York City when it was barred from the St. Patrick's Day parade, he was forced into a leave of absence from his Order and active ministry. After a few years, he was told that he would never be able to function as a priest again. Devastated, but still committed to gay ministry, he sought creative ways by which he could continue his ministry. He discovered the Independent Catholic Movement and made inquiries into one such denomination. He started a parish for this church, but realized that he would sacrifice his priesthood. However, his new superior told him that his celebrating Mass for this new Church caused his automatic excommunication from the Church and expulsion from the Order. Cut off from his religious family and beloved Church, he later joined the Ecumenical Catholic Church. Within a relatively short time of rapid growth, the ECC appointed him as bishop of the new diocese of New England. Unfortunately, this community broke with the ECC in its attempts to be less patriarchal and more egalitarian and ecumenical, without loss of Catholic identity. The American Apostolic Catholic Church was born from this experience, embracing lay and ordained persons who share authority; women and men are ordained; all persons are offered the seven sacraments. However, this denomination was not able to satisfy Richard's longing to be a part of the Church Universal in living out his baptismal commitment and his dedication to social justice for the g/l/b/t community. Thus, in May 2000, he was welcomed into the Episcopal Church and into membership within the Anglo-Catholic Parish of Grace Church in Hartford. He continued to participate in gay causes and in Dignity/USA until his death.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged alphabetically by the subject title of the folder. Series I includes Richard Carderelli's personal correspondence files, writings, and files he kept on various topics, especially Dignity, which comprises two large boxes of folders. Series II is comprised of photographs and scrapbooks. Series III is comprised of videotapes and one audio cassette. Series IV is comprised of a Lectionary and Sacramentary from Dignity/Hartford, and other realia, including T-Shirts from various events and organizations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Richard Cardarelli Papers contain primarily his own personal research and reference files. These include files pertaining to Dignity/Hartford for the period 1975 to 2003. The bulk of the collection are subject files kept by Cardarelli, and several scrapbooks of photos pertaining to events in which he was involved. Interspersed within the files are his own correspondence and writings. The realia includes T-shirts, a lectionary and sacramentary from Dignity/Hartford, and various momentos from Richard Cardarelli's religious activities, activism and conferences.

relatedmaterial.head: Oral history interview
relatedmaterial.p: An oral history interview of Richard Cardarelli is available within the Digital Collections of the GLTBQ Archives on the website of the Elihu Burritt Library.
